awd_titl_txt: CT-ISG:   User-Aided Secure Association of Wireless Devices
awd_abstract_narration:
The popularity of personal gadgets opens up many new services for ordinary users. Many everyday usage scenarios involve two or more devices "working together". (Emerging scenarios are beginning to involve sensors and personal RFID tags.) Before working together, devices must be securely "paired" to enable secure and private communication. 

However, the human-imperceptible nature of wireless communication prompts the very real threat of Man-in-the-Middle (MiTM) attacks. Another challenge arises due to the lack of a global security infrastructure. Consequently, traditional cryptographic means alone are unsuitable, since unfamiliar devices have no prior security context and no common point of trust. Therefore, some human involvement in secure device pairing is unavoidable. At the same time, most devices have limited hardware and/or user interfaces, thus complicating human involvement.

This project?s goals are three-fold: (1) design a set of pairing methods suitable for most common devices and a general user population, based on comprehensive and comparative usability studies, (2) develop secure pairing techniques for personal RFID tags, and (3) construct a set of user-friendly, scalable and secure methods for sensor initialization.

Benefits of this project will include accumulation of valuable expertise in designing truly usable security methods.  Notably, the project expects to experimentally assess the value of usable security with respect to the general population.  Furthermore, the need for, and the utility of, user-centric secure control of personal RFID tags and sensors will be demonstrated. Since device pairing is one of the very few areas where security directly involves and affects the average user, the greatest impact of proposed research is expected to be the broader participation in security practices and better appreciation of security and its benefits.  The project also emphasizes industry outreach and technology transfer by working with manufacturers and industrial consortia.

In addition, students taking part in the project are expected to acquire currently uncommon skills at the cusp of Human-Computer Interaction, Usability and Cyber Trust.

This project dealt with the problem of secure association of wireless devices and led to several publications [1-21]. Most notable publication venues include: TIFS’13, TMC'12, TIFS'11, CHI'11, CCS'10, Ubicomp'10, Percom'09, PMC'09, and SOUPS'08. One of the main challenges that we strived to address in this project was the design and usability evaluation of “universal" pairing techniques (e.g., [8, 10, 11, 13, 14, 15, 16]), which can be used even on low-end devices with constrained interfaces (e.g., access points or headsets). We performed the first comparative usability evaluation of a large number of device pairing methods [4, 5]. We extended this study to an emerging “two-user" (social) pairing setting [6], to more challenging group scenarios [7], and to multiple device environments (e.g., sensor networks) [13, 20]. We demonstrated, via another study [1], that human perception of distances is far from accurate and that secure association using distance bounding techniques may not be feasible. Moreover, we demonstrated [2, 21] the vulnerabilities of certain pairing approaches geared for constrained devices (e.g., medical implants [58]), a problem that essentially stems from a combination of human and device constraints. Furthermore, we have designed and developed simple computer games and rewarding functionalities [17, 18, 19] that can enhance the security and usability of device pairing.

Our research has provided valuable insights on users' perception of security and their behavior vis-a-vis an important security task (secure association). Most critically, we have found that, even in this relatively new application domain, users' perception of security is unreal. Users lack motivation to diligently participate in association procedures. They make mistakes even at simple tasks (e.g., number comparison) and may seek workarounds to them (e.g., just hit “accept" without paying attention). These issues can only get exacerbated in real world usage (in contrast to lab studies). Consequently, this may lead to poor security and privacy in practice, despite the theoretical security guarantees provided by the underlying cryptographic protocols. This further motivates the need for more research in this topic. We believe that our research provides strong foundation over which secure and usable pairing mechanisms can be produced.
